attributes.title: R21AA025716 Momentary Assessment of Cognitive Bias and its Relation to Adolescent Alcohol Use
attributes.description: Momentary Assessment of Cognitive Bias and its Relation to Adolescent Alcohol Use

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
R21AA025716:  Momentary Assessment of Cognitive Bias and its Relation to Adolescent
Alcohol Use: Secondary Aim

sample.value: 120 participants will contribute 17 days of EMA data, with 4 scheduled and up to 2 optional (self-initiated) surveys when drinking.

analyses.value: Multilevel Factor Analysis in an SEM framework

outliers.value: Task data will be evaluated to exclude erroneous responses using strategies previously outlined by other users of the alcohol Stroop and Approach Avoidance tasks.

dependent.value: Cognitive bias towards alcohol will be assessed at the momentary level using two reaction time tasks administered via phone. First, we will assess attentional bias towards alcohol using an alcohol-Stroop task adapted from Bauer & Cox (1998) in a manner similar to Waters, Marhe, and Franken (2012). Second, we will assess alcohol-approach bias with an Approach-Avoidance Task (Wiers et al., 2009), adapted for use with a mobile phone touchscreen interface.

hypothesis.value: Secondary Aim: to examine the convergent validity and unique predictive power of momentary cognitive bias assessment relative to a standard laboratory based cognitive bias assessment.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

Alcohol Use: Secondary Aim

attributes.title: R21AA025716 Momentary Assessment of Cognitive Bias and its Relation to Adolescent Alcohol Use

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
R21AA025716:  Momentary Assessment of Cognitive Bias and its Relation to Adolescent
Alcohol Use: Primary Aim 3

sample.value: 120 participants will contribute 17 days of EMA data, with 4 scheduled and up to 2 optional (self-initiated) surveys when drinking.

outliers.value: Task data will be evaluated to exclude erroneous responses using strategies previously outlined by other users of the alcohol Stroop and Approach Avoidance tasks.

dependent.value:
Drinking and context will be assessed via momentary surveys administered on participants' smartphones.

Cognitive bias towards alcohol will be assessed at the momentary level using two reaction time tasks administered via phone. First, we will assess attentional bias towards alcohol using an alcohol-Stroop task adapted from Bauer & Cox (1998) in a manner similar to Waters, Marhe, and Franken (2012). Second, we will assess alcohol-approach bias with an Approach-Avoidance Task (Wiers et al., 2009), adapted for use with a mobile phone touchscreen interface.

hypothesis.value: Primary Aim 3: Test whether Social and environmental context, as well as the effects of acute alcohol use, heighten or lessen the effects of cognitive bias on subsequent alcohol use.

attributes.title: Exploring Category Structure in Children and Adults using MDS

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Exploring Category Structure in Children and Adults using MDS

other.value:
We will evaluate age-group differences, as well as feature importance by fitting a hierarchical MDS model to our similarities  (Okada & Lee, 2016). 
Data collection for children started on 24/11/2019 and on 15/01/2020 for adults, but no data has been inspected and no analysis has been performed.

sample.value: For each age group, we will collect participants until 30 non-excluded participants are acquired. Thus we will acquire a total of 30*3 (4-5year-olds, 6-7year-olds, adults) = 90 participants.

analyses.value:
We will aggregate the selected pairs by age group (4-5,6-7, adults) and construct combined psychological spaces. Then we will compare these spaces across age groups. 
To construct the spaces we will infer the distances from same-different pairs of fruits by learning an invariant mapping, using the method described by Hadsell & LeCun (2006). This allows us to infer two types of age-related differences: 
1) The dimension of the best-fitting solution
2) Distributional properties of the learned spaces, such as the number of clusters or distances between (dimension-aligned) spaces.

outliers.value: Participants that do not select the very similar fruit in the pretest task (either as a first or second choice) will be excluded. Furthermore, participants that select more than 32 (out of 36 possible, 90%) singleton groups, and participants that place more than 32 into a single box (90%) will be excluded.

dependent.value: Participants will select cards with pictures of cartoon fruits on them, and sort them into groups, where each group corresponds to what that participant deems to be the same kind of fruit. Those groups will be used to construct the similarity between fruits. The pictures of the fruits are generated programmatically and vary by color, size, and shape following the method in Sanborn et al. (2010).

conditions.value: All participants will engage in the same sorting task. Participants will receive a different randomly chosen set of fruit stimuli to group (a set of 36 out of 180 possible fruits).

hypothesis.value: Do the psychological spaces that underpin categorical reasoning differ throughout development?

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

attributes.title: Alone in a Crowd of Sheep: Replication and Extension of Pronin et al. (2007)

q1.value: Alone in a Crowd of Sheep: Replication and Extension of Pronin et al. (2007)

q3.value: This study is a replication of Pronin et al.'s (2007) Study 2.  In addition to replicating their study, we also included an additional condition where participants are asked to make judgments about a close friend.

q4.value:
1. For the self condition, participants will have higher desirability judgments in the desirable condition vs. the undesirable condition.

2. For the self condition, both the undesirable and desirable conditions will rate their conformity as less than the average ASU student (4 in our study).

 ---
3. For the friend condition, participants will have higher desirability judgments in the desirable condition vs. the undesirable condition.

4. For the friend condition, participants from both the undesirable and desirable conditions will rate their conformity as similar to the average ASU student (4 in our study).
---

5. Comparing the self and friend conditions, participants will report that they conform less than their friend does relative to the average ASU student.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 2 factors. The first factor (desirability) has 2 levels (desirable and undesirable). The second factor (target) also has two levels (self and close friend).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Appalachian's online SONA system. Participants will be given 1 ELC credit towards their psychology class for participation in this study. Participants must be at least 18 years old to participate in this online study.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 240 participants.

q14.value: Our target sample size was at least 60 participants per condition (240 total). This would give us more than 3 times the sample size (per condition) of the study we were replicating.

question.value: We manipulated the desirability of a paragraph about conforming when purchasing an iPhone (desirable or undesirable condition). We also manipulated whether the questions evaluated the self vs. others or a close friend vs. others (self or friend condition).

We will measure perceived desirability of conforming when purchasing an iPhone in both the self and friend condition (on a scale of 1-7, 1 = very undesirable, 7 = very desirable) and perception of conformity compared to the average ASU student in both the self and friend condition (on a scale of 1-7, 1 = much less than the average ASU student, 7 = much more than the average ASU student).

1. Independent samples t-test comparing desirability judgments in desirable condition and undesirable condition, for the self.

2. One sample t-test comparing people’s comparative judgments with the scale midpoint (4)

3. Two one sample t-tests comparing people’s comparative judgments with the scale midpoint (4). 1 test for the undesirable condition, 1 for the desirable condition.
---
4. Independent samples t-test comparing desirability judgments in desirable condition and undesirable condition, for the friend.

5. One sample t-test comparing people’s comparative judgments with the scale midpoint (4)

6. Two one sample t-tests comparing people’s comparative judgments with the scale midpoint (4). 1 test for the undesirable condition, 1 for the desirable condition.
---
7. 2 (target: self vs. other) x 2 (desirability: undesirable vs. desirable) ANOVA on people’s comparative conformity judgments.

q22.value: Participants must indicate they own an iPhone.

---

attributes.title: Empathy in couples as a predictor of responsiveness towards infant's cry in the situation of parental role's activation - mediational role of oxcytocin and vasopressin (HEART model)

summary.value:
Empathy is viewed as the basis for human relationships, and it is often associated with responding to others’ pain, and therefore linked to compassion and helping behaviors. In theories in the domain of developmental and family psychology parental empathy and its expression to children is viewed as the essential component of the childrearing process, important for their development. New research indicate genetic factors linked to oxytocin (OT) and vasopressin (AVP) as significant for empathy, and those hormones levels’ changes as predictors of parental sensitivity. The question arises whether dispositional empathy in couples facilitates responses towards child’s signals linked to discomfort and promoting attachment in the caretaking situation, partially due to hormonal factors? 

To respond to such a question reactions of more or less empathic adults to infant’s cry will be explored in the presented project – a new subject in the area of empathy research. The proposed model is named HEART - HORMONALLY mediated EMPATHY role for AFFILIATIVE RESPONSE towards infants TEARS. Mediational role of hormonal levels and their changes between empathy and responsiveness towards infant’s cry is emphasized. The project is interdisciplinary. It merges psychological and physiological factors shaping responsiveness towards child’s signals, stressing the importance of individual differences for the functioning of couples in the context of parental roles. Romantic couples will be invited to participate in the project: childless (110 couples), and expecting their first child (110 couples).  All participants will participate in the experimental procedure with the infant simulator LISSA- a life-like doll, which cries as programmed during the interaction with a caretaker. During this carefully planned procedure 4 salivary samples will be collected from each partner to measure basal and changed levels of salivary OT and AVP, and to gather genetic material for genotyping of polymorphisms in OXTR, AVPR1a and CD38 genes. Sensitivity during experimental sessions (contact with LISSA: 1. individual; 2. in couples) will be assessed with the Ainsworth Sensitivity Scale (observational measure). Additionally, to measure other psychological variables participants will fill in carefully chosen, psychological instruments.  

Therefore, the issues essential for the quality of family life and child’s development will be explored in the project. We will seek for the answers for questions about the bases or roots of the role of empathy in displaying sensitivity towards children’s needs and thus in creating adult-child bonds. In times of praise of independence, with increased social isolation in societies, and increasing frequency of divorce and pathology in families, a deepened analysis of ‘a social glue’, that is empathy, for responsiveness to child’s needs is required.

attributes.title: Will you hear what I hear? Predictive Coding in Simple Presentation of Western Tonal Music
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

additionalComments.value: There is still space for the details herein to be modified for any reason.

question2a.value:
The type of prediction violation (Within-participant variable)
	Small violation: the correct tone, or note, but in the wrong octave
	Large violation: a completely incorrect tone, or note

question3b.value: Type of instrumental training - for further analysis within the musicians experimental group

question10b.value:
Prior to beginning the experimental procedure, a brief demographic questionnaire will be given to participants with the following questions:

1.	How old are you?
2.	What is your gender?
3.	Do you currently play a musical instrument?
a.	Is it a keyboard instrument, such as piano, organ, etc.?
b.	How long have you played the instrument?

The entire experimental procedure will take place using a computer.  First, the melody that will be used throughout the experiment will be played once in order for the participant to adjust the volume to their ideal level.  The melody used will be the basic 7 note arpeggio (do mi so do' so mi do) in changing keys.  The testing session will be broken down into three short blocks as follows with the same instructions for each block:

Instructions: A brief melody, consisting of 7 notes will be played.  Press 1 if the first, fourth, and final note are the same.  Press 2 if they are not.  Please respond as quickly as possible.  If there is no response, the next melody will be played after 10 seconds.

Block 1:  All small violations, where the changed note will be the final note
Block 2: All large violations, where the changed note will be the final note
Block 3: A mix of small and large violations, where the changed note will be the final note
	
	The experiment will conclude by asking the participants the following question and 
instructions:

	Please press 1 for yes or press 2 for no.
	
	Have you heard this melody before partaking in this experiment?

All violations will be mixed with correct versions of the melody.  Whether or not a violation or correct melody will be randomly selected by the computer program, however, there will be the same number of each presented per block.  Reaction times and responses will be recorded by the computer, as will accuracy of the participants.  All of this will be done utilizing MatLab and computer-generated tones.

question5b.value: Data will be collected from students at the University of St Andrews.  Data will be collected using a computer and associated keyboard.  Collection will occur from late February through March.  The planned, minimum sample size is 10 – 15 participants per group (musician and non-musician).

question6b.value: Most previous research has focused on a sample size between 5 and 30 participants (see references in rationale).  The aim is to have a larger overall sample size.

question7b.value: There will be a set number of trials per block, which will remain the same across all blocks of testing.  As many participants as possible will be tested before 1st April 2020, when the experiment concludes.

question8b.value: One exclusion applies to the planned sample: if a participant previously received musical training, but no longer plays the instrument, they will not be able to partake.   Furthermore, all response times will be limited to 10 seconds.

question6c.value: A correction for multiple comparisons could be applied - likely a Bonferroni correction

question1a.value:
1.	Musicians will have a significantly shorter reaction time when there is a small violation in prediction compared to non-musicians 
2.	Musicians will have a significantly shorter reaction time when there is a large violation in prediction compared to non-musicians
3.	Musicians that have been trained on keyboard instruments will have shorter reaction times in both conditions compared to musicians that have been trained on other instruments

question2a.value: Within the musicians group, those with training on a keyboard based instrument will have the shorted reaction times

question3a.value: There is not a manipulation check included.  Participants will not begin on the same baseline due to examining differences between musicians and non-musicians.  There is also not a manipulation check on the violation - the aim of the experiment is to violate the expectations and predictions of the participants.

question5a.value: For hypotheses 1 and 2, there has been a plethora of research examining these differences that utilize different methods.  Specifically, the most common are neuroimaging studies using EEG and MEG to examine Mismatch Negativity (MMN) (Burunat et al., 2015; Alluri et al., 2017; Boer et al., 2013; Heilbron & Chait, 2018; Wacongne, Changeux & Dehaene, 2012; Barascud et al., 2016; Zatorre & Salimpoor, 2013; etc.).  Other research has determined differences between musicians and non-musicians using self-generated sounds, where musicians will react faster due to training that has strengthened connections and sensory-motor integration (Krala et al., 2019, Reznik et al., 2015. Musicians have reacted faster than non-musicians to generate the desired sound. Furthermore, for the 3rd hypothesis, research has shown that musicians trained on different instruments will have different structure-function relationships in cortical and subcortical areas, in addition to different physical manifestations of this (Bangert & Altenmüller, 2003, Burunat et al., 2015, Drost et al. 2005a, Drost et al., 2005b, Vollman et al., 2014).

question1c.value:
Type of Violation 
Reaction Times, as recorded by the computer
        Mean reaction times for each group will be calculated as well

question3c.value:
IV - type of violation
DV - reaction time
Mediator - experimental group

question1c.value:
Type of Violation 
Reaction Times, as recorded by the computer
        Mean reaction times for each group will be calculated as well

question3c.value:
IV - type of violation
DV - reaction time

question1c.value:
Type of Violation

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun
registration_responses.additionalComments: There is still space for the details herein to be modified for any reason.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
1.	Musicians will have a significantly shorter reaction time when there is a small violation in prediction compared to non-musicians 
2.	Musicians will have a significantly shorter reaction time when there is a large violation in prediction compared to non-musicians
3.	Musicians that have been trained on keyboard instruments will have shorter reaction times in both conditions compared to musicians that have been trained on other instruments
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a: Within the musicians group, those with training on a keyboard based instrument will have the shorted reaction times
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: There is not a manipulation check included.  Participants will not begin on the same baseline due to examining differences between musicians and non-musicians.  There is also not a manipulation check on the violation - the aim of the experiment is to violate the expectations and predictions of the participants.
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a: For hypotheses 1 and 2, there has been a plethora of research examining these differences that utilize different methods.  Specifically, the most common are neuroimaging studies using EEG and MEG to examine Mismatch Negativity (MMN) (Burunat et al., 2015; Alluri et al., 2017; Boer et al., 2013; Heilbron & Chait, 2018; Wacongne, Changeux & Dehaene, 2012; Barascud et al., 2016; Zatorre & Salimpoor, 2013; etc.).  Other research has determined differences between musicians and non-musicians using self-generated sounds, where musicians will react faster due to training that has strengthened connections and sensory-motor integration (Krala et al., 2019, Reznik et al., 2015. Musicians have reacted faster than non-musicians to generate the desired sound. Furthermore, for the 3rd hypothesis, research has shown that musicians trained on different instruments will have different structure-function relationships in cortical and subcortical areas, in addition to different physical manifestations of this (Bangert & Altenmüller, 2003, Burunat et al., 2015, Drost et al. 2005a, Drost et al., 2005b, Vollman et al., 2014).
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
The type of prediction violation (Within-participant variable)
	Small violation: the correct tone, or note, but in the wrong octave
	Large violation: a completely incorrect tone, or note
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: Type of instrumental training - for further analysis within the musicians experimental group
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question6c: A correction for multiple comparisons could be applied - likely a Bonferroni correction
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Prior to beginning the experimental procedure, a brief demographic questionnaire will be given to participants with the following questions:

1.	How old are you?
2.	What is your gender?
3.	Do you currently play a musical instrument?
a.	Is it a keyboard instrument, such as piano, organ, etc.?
b.	How long have you played the instrument?

The entire experimental procedure will take place using a computer.  First, the melody that will be used throughout the experiment will be played once in order for the participant to adjust the volume to their ideal level.  The melody used will be the basic 7 note arpeggio (do mi so do' so mi do) in changing keys.  The testing session will be broken down into three short blocks as follows with the same instructions for each block:

Instructions: A brief melody, consisting of 7 notes will be played.  Press 1 if the first, fourth, and final note are the same.  Press 2 if they are not.  Please respond as quickly as possible.  If there is no response, the next melody will be played after 10 seconds.

Block 1:  All small violations, where the changed note will be the final note
Block 2: All large violations, where the changed note will be the final note
Block 3: A mix of small and large violations, where the changed note will be the final note
	
	The experiment will conclude by asking the participants the following question and 
instructions:

	Please press 1 for yes or press 2 for no.
	
	Have you heard this melody before partaking in this experiment?

All violations will be mixed with correct versions of the melody.  Whether or not a violation or correct melody will be randomly selected by the computer program, however, there will be the same number of each presented per block.  Reaction times and responses will be recorded by the computer, as will accuracy of the participants.  All of this will be done utilizing MatLab and computer-generated tones.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:

IV - type of violation
DV - reaction time
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Data will be collected from students at the University of St Andrews.  Data will be collected using a computer and associated keyboard.  Collection will occur from late February through March.  The planned, minimum sample size is 10 – 15 participants per group (musician and non-musician).
Most previous research has focused on a sample size between 5 and 30 participants (see references in rationale).  The aim is to have a larger overall sample size.

There will be a set number of trials per block, which will remain the same across all blocks of testing.  As many participants as possible will be tested before 1st April 2020, when the experiment concludes.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques:
Type of Violation 
Reaction Times, as recorded by the computer
        Mean reaction times for each group will be calculated as well

IV - type of violation
DV - reaction time
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: One exclusion applies to the planned sample: if a participant previously received musical training, but no longer plays the instrument, they will not be able to partake.   Furthermore, all response times will be limited to 10 seconds.

attributes.title: Does eyes direction encourage a more specific attentional orienting as compared to arrows?

q1.value: Reducing cognitive load with multi-day accent training

q2.value: Drew Jordan McLaughlin, Melissa Baese-Berk, Kristin Van Engen

q3.value:
Evidence suggests that listeners rapidly “tune” to unfamiliar accented speech, improving their ability to understand a given speaker over time. For second language- (L2-) accented speech, this perceptual adaptation can be facilitated by exposure to a single accented speaker, by exposure to multiple speakers with the same accent, or even by exposure to a variety of speakers with different accents (Bradlow & Bent, 2008; Sidaras, Alexander, & Nygaard, 2009; Baese-Berk, Bradlow, & Wright, 2013). In addition to improving listener recognition of speech (i.e., intelligibility), cognitive processing load also rapidly decreases with exposure to L2-accented speech (Brown, McLaughlin, Strand, & Van Engen, under review). 

The present study aims to measure adaptation to unfamiliar accented speech over multiple days using a dual-task paradigm to measure cognitive processing load. Days 1 and 5 will be pre- and post-test days, respectively, and Days 2, 3, and 4 will be training days. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: control (no exposure to accent or feedback during training), exposure (exposure to accent but no feedback during training), and feedback (exposure to accent and feedback during training). All groups will have the same pre- and post-test with native- and L2-accented speech stimuli. Measures of cognitive control (inhibition) and working memory will also be assessed and compared with pre- and post-test data.

q4.value:
We predict that response times in the secondary task will be shorter on Day 5 than Day 1 for all groups (indicating improvement on the task itself), but that the training groups, exposure and feedback, will show greater improvement in the L2-accented speech condition than the control group. We also predict that the feedback group will show greater improvement than the exposure group.

We will also test for changes in intelligibility from pre- to post-test, where we think there could be measurable improvement. Similar to the RT data, intelligibility scores from the primary task may be larger on Day 5 than Day 1 for all groups (indicating improvement on the task itself), and the training groups, exposure and feedback, may show greater improvement in the L2-accented speech condition than the control group. The feedback group may also show greater improvement than the exposure group. We expect that it is also possible that improvements may only be found for the RT (cognitive load) measure and not intelligibility.

For Days 2, 3, and 4, there will also be intelligibility data that we can examine. We predict that, if any differences exist, the feedback group will have higher intelligibility scores than the exposure group overall, and that there will be an interaction with days, reflecting greater improvement for the feedback group over time. However, we also expect that differences in intelligibility may not be found between groups.

We predict that cognitive measures of inhibition and working memory will predict overall intelligibility of L2-accented speech, overall response time for L2-accented speech trials, and improvement of RTs (i.e., adaptation) from pre- to post-test.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study will have a mixed design. Subjects will be randomly assignment to groups, requiring between-group comparisons, but all other variables of the experiment will be within-subject. Thus, there will be repeated measures for comparing between the native and L2 accent conditions, and for comparing between Day 1 and Day 5.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This study will examine young adult subjects recruited from the Washington University Psychology Subject Pool. Participants will receive course credit in exchange for participation. 

Participants will be excluded from analyses if they are not a native speaker of English, have abnormal hearing, personally speak with a Mandarin accent, or report having substantial previous exposure to Mandarin-accented English (i.e., have roommates, parents, or close family members who speak with a Mandarin accent, or have taken Mandarin in a classroom setting).

q14.value: We conducted a simulation-based power analysis using pilot data and found that at 60 subjects per group (180 subjects total) we should have greater than 80% power to find the main effects of interest.

question.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: control (no exposure to accent or feedback during training), exposure (exposure to accent but no feedback during training), and feedback (exposure to accent and feedback during training). All groups will have the same pre- and post-test with native- and L2-accented speech conditions, but on the training days (Days 2, 3, and 4) each group will receive different trainings. The control group will listen to target sentences recorded by the native-accented speakers, and the exposure and feedback groups will listen to the same target sentences recorded by L2-accented speakers. All participants will be instructed to type what they heard after each sentence, and then, for the feedback group only, the target sentence will be displayed as feedback.

In the listening task, we will measure response time to the secondary task (Days 1 and 5 only) and recognition accuracy (all days). Using questionnaires, we will ascertain demographic and language background information about each participant on Day 1, and on the training days we will assess motivation.

In the working memory task, we will measure capacity (a scale limited between one and six), in the Stroop task, we will measure the number of words correctly identified, and in the Trail Making Task, we will measure the time required to complete the task.

Following the same steps as Scullin et al. (2011), a composite of the Trail Making and Stroop task scores will be made for statistical modeling if the two measures are highly correlated (as we expect to be the case). If needed, the scores will be transformed so that the direction of the two tasks matches (that is, lower scores should indicate worse inhibition in both), and then the z-scores of each measure will be averaged.

For Days 1 and 5, we will use three generalized linear mixed effects models to compare the response times (dependent variable) of the random assignment groups. These models will include identity link functions, assuming an inverse Gaussian distribution and thus controlling for the abnormal skew of the response time data. Model 1 will include data from the control and exposure groups, Model 2 from the control and feedback groups, and Model 3 from the exposure and feedback groups. The same main effects will be included in all three models: condition (native versus nonnative), day (Day 1 versus Day 5), group, and all possible two- and three-way interactions between condition, day, and group. Likelihood ratio tests will be used to determine whether inhibition and working memory (and their interactions with the other main effects) improve model fit, and, if so, they will be added to the model. Random effects will include intercepts and slopes of subjects and items. This same process will be repeated to examine intelligibility as a dependent variable.

For Days 2, 3, and 4, we will use a single additional model to compare the recognition accuracy between the exposure and feedback groups. The main effects will include group, day (ordered 2, 3, then 4), and the interaction between group and day, and, if they improve model fit, inhibition, working memory, and the interaction between each cognitive measure and day. Random effects will include intercepts and slopes of subjects and items.

Additional correlations will be calculated with the cognitive measures. First, the correlations between scores on the two inhibition tasks and the working memory task will all be calculated. Next, correlations of working memory and the composite inhibition measure will be calculated with average intelligibility scores for the L2 accent condition (Day 1 only), and then with Day 1 response time difference scores (i.e., the mean of the L2-accented condition minus the mean of the native-accented condition, for each subject); in all cases intelligibility and response time data from all three random assignment groups will be collapsed.

q21.value: A significance threshold of p < .05 will be applied.

q22.value:
For the response time (RT) data, trials with RTs that are three median absolute deviations (MADs) above or below a given subject’s median RT, within a given day and within a given condition, will be considered outliers and excluded from analyses. Additionally, RTs on any trials in which the wrong response was made (e.g., a left instead of a right keypress) will be excluded from analyses. 

After excluding trials for the reasons above, the amount of data loss for a given subject within a given day and condition will be calculated (four separate values per subject). Subjects will be excluded from the pre- versus post-test analyses if they have more than 25% data loss in any one or more of these conditions/days. 

Participants will also be excluded from all analyses if their mean word accuracy score is three standard deviations above or below the word accuracy mean of all subjects. The assumption being that they were unengaged in one of the two simultaneous tasks, and, thus, not following directions.

Participants will also be excluded if they do not meet the eligibility criteria.

q23.value: Generalized mixed effects models are fairly robust against missing data, so we don’t expect this to be an issue.

q25.value: Scoring intelligibility: Keywords in target sentences will be scored for how many of the words were correctly transcribed (training days) or repeated aloud (test days). Research assistants will be blinded as to the condition that each target and response belongs to. Words will be scored as correct if they match the given target word exactly, or if they differ in only plurality or tense.

registration_responses.q1: Reducing cognitive load with multi-day accent training
registration_responses.q2: Drew Jordan McLaughlin, Melissa Baese-Berk, Kristin Van Engen
registration_responses.q3:
Evidence suggests that listeners rapidly “tune” to unfamiliar accented speech, improving their ability to understand a given speaker over time. For second language- (L2-) accented speech, this perceptual adaptation can be facilitated by exposure to a single accented speaker, by exposure to multiple speakers with the same accent, or even by exposure to a variety of speakers with different accents (Bradlow & Bent, 2008; Sidaras, Alexander, & Nygaard, 2009; Baese-Berk, Bradlow, & Wright, 2013). In addition to improving listener recognition of speech (i.e., intelligibility), cognitive processing load also rapidly decreases with exposure to L2-accented speech (Brown, McLaughlin, Strand, & Van Engen, under review). 

The present study aims to measure adaptation to unfamiliar accented speech over multiple days using a dual-task paradigm to measure cognitive processing load. Days 1 and 5 will be pre- and post-test days, respectively, and Days 2, 3, and 4 will be training days. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: control (no exposure to accent or feedback during training), exposure (exposure to accent but no feedback during training), and feedback (exposure to accent and feedback during training). All groups will have the same pre- and post-test with native- and L2-accented speech stimuli. Measures of cognitive control (inhibition) and working memory will also be assessed and compared with pre- and post-test data.
registration_responses.q4:
We predict that response times in the secondary task will be shorter on Day 5 than Day 1 for all groups (indicating improvement on the task itself), but that the training groups, exposure and feedback, will show greater improvement in the L2-accented speech condition than the control group. We also predict that the feedback group will show greater improvement than the exposure group.

We will also test for changes in intelligibility from pre- to post-test, where we think there could be measurable improvement. Similar to the RT data, intelligibility scores from the primary task may be larger on Day 5 than Day 1 for all groups (indicating improvement on the task itself), and the training groups, exposure and feedback, may show greater improvement in the L2-accented speech condition than the control group. The feedback group may also show greater improvement than the exposure group. We expect that it is also possible that improvements may only be found for the RT (cognitive load) measure and not intelligibility.

For Days 2, 3, and 4, there will also be intelligibility data that we can examine. We predict that, if any differences exist, the feedback group will have higher intelligibility scores than the exposure group overall, and that there will be an interaction with days, reflecting greater improvement for the feedback group over time. However, we also expect that differences in intelligibility may not be found between groups.

We predict that cognitive measures of inhibition and working memory will predict overall intelligibility of L2-accented speech, overall response time for L2-accented speech trials, and improvement of RTs (i.e., adaptation) from pre- to post-test.
